Hard numbers are hard to come by, but it is highly probably that the number of kids currently taking Karate lessons in the United States would be in the hundreds of thousands, if not more. You just type a term like 'Karate lessons for kids' on your search engine, and the huge number of centers offering the lessons that the search yields aver to the fact that there is great demand for the lessons. After all, if all those centers offering the lessons are managing to remain in business, and seemingly thrive, then clearly, there must be demand for the service they are offering.

The critical thinker will, however, be more interested in understanding the factors driving that growing popularity of kids karate lessons. Those are, in effect, the attractions to the said lessons.

As it turns out, one of the factors behind the growing popularity of karate lessons for kids is that in them, parents see a fun way to get their kids off the couches. Many of us are already familiar with the predicament facing us: where kids are getting into sedentary lifestyles too early in their lives, the end result being the kids' obesity pandemic currently facing most of the developed world. And this is happening at a point when the age of whipping kids into physical activity is long gone. Today, if you want your kids to lead an active lifestyle, you have to find ways of getting them to do so out of their own volition. And kids will normally only do something willingly if they perceive it as 'fun.' Now karate, correctly taught, comes across as such - and the kids are bound to love it, thus willingly getting them off the couches.

Another factor behind the growing popularity of kids karate lessons is that in those lessons, parents see the opportunity to have their kids learn the much needed self defense skills in today's world. That is after taking cognizance of the fact that in spite of the world being a much developed place today, there are still people who are yet to evolve out of the savagery which is physical confrontation tendencies. War is still a basic fact of life. Sometimes, the ability to physically defend oneself actually becomes a life and death matter. And as we all know, the best time for physical skill acquisition is during the childhood, hence the desire by many parents to have their kids on karate lessons as early as reasonably possible.

Yet another reason behind the growing popularity of karate lessons for kids is that it has been demonstrated that practice of the martial arts correlates favorably with high levels of self discipline. Previously, it was thought that it was because people were self disciplined that they would be inclined towards taking up the martial arts. But increasingly, it is being realized that the inverse is also true, where people who practice martial arts consistently eventually develop high levels of self discipline. And naturally, every parent who is cognizant of the relationship between high levels of self discipline and life happiness (as well as success) would want their kid to have such high levels of self discipline. Upon learning that one of the ways they can help their kids develop high degrees of self discipline is by enrolling them for kids karate lessons, that is exactly what they proceed to do.

Fight or flight is an interesting choice. For most people, however, it is not a choice, but something they do blindly, no choice at all.

Wake up!
If a dog snaps at you, there is intuitive movement. The movement is always away. Teeth win, hand lose, no contest, get the heck outa Dodge.

If a human being snaps at you...hmm. Most people jump back, enter into flight mode. The problem is that it is a blind reaction. And, unfortunately, the few people who leap at the snapper...it is a blind reaction for them, too. Just a slightly different blindness.

So what if your back was to a cliff, and a human snapped at you. Would you jump off the cliff? I mean, when do you start making choices? In this scenario your choice comes about because the fall off a cliff would hurt more than a snapping human. Surprisingly, most people would jump off a cliff.

When you study martial arts you change that. At first, you get a little hair trigger. Somebody growls at you, and you growl back before you even think about what you are doing. And if they snap at you, they end up with a fist in their eye.

But what if it is granny that tapped you on the back late at night? In that scenario you just knocked granny's false teeth out, armlocked her to the ground and stepped on her spindly, little neck. Grandpa ain't gonna be too happy about that.

So you have to get past flight AND fight as blind responses. You must train until you move from choice, and not from reaction.

When you do this, when you gain choice in your actions, no matter what the threat or how severe, you have increased your awareness. Or, to put it another way, you have woken up.

Man, you see, is asleep...dreaming that he is awake. It's true.

That guy filling out the voting form? He's as blind as the guy pulling the silver arm in a casino. Throw away money or throw away future...or throw away a whole country...it is a form of unconsciousness.

You, reading this. You are only dreaming that you are reading this. You're actually asleep, and you will finish this bit of eye exercise and continue to be asleep.

So, want to wake up? Do the martial arts. Learn Karate or Tai Chi or something. Become aware of all your potentials and choices. Stop dreaming that you're awake and...AWAKE!

Nearly every day more studies and research are pointing to the multiple and various benefits of traditional training programs especially those that are taught through martial arts classes to children across the globe. Yes, contrary to most beliefs, teaching your child any type of skill form like Taekwondo, Judo or Karate is not going to make them aggressive or violent. On the contrary, if taught in the authentic way, these classes can really enhance your children's personality and aid in healthy development of their mind, body and spirit in a completely holistic manner.

The Real Essence of Martial Arts

While enrolling your kids into martial arts classes can help them to learn effective techniques for defending themselves from getting bullied in class or outside, the key role of this training is much more than just teaching children about self-defense. Traditional schools like the ones that teach Taekwondo, Karate or Tai Chi are based on the tenets of absorbing the spirit of peace, compassion, justice, self-control and discipline amongst the students. Students who are initiated into Taekwondo martial arts classes take a pledge to never misuse their power and to apply compassion and peaceful living in all aspects of their lives. Understanding these facts about the basic value system of martial arts helps us further understanding the holistic influence of these practices in our lives.

Exclusive Martial Arts Classes for Children

With more and more parents becoming aware of the various benefits of enrolling their children in these classes, there has been a significant upsurge in the types of training programs that are now available for children. From traditional taekwondo, karate and judo lessons to training programs that have been customized for children with special needs, parents can now find the type of martial art form that will be perfectly suited for their children.

Certain schools are also offering a contemporary form of teaching plan through which kids learn about various types of martial art techniques that are fused into one basic training program to make the classes all the more interesting and engaging. It is a great idea to begin young children through these integrated classes, before graduating into a particular discipline like Taekwondo or Judo or any other form as they grow older.

The Holistic Benefits of Martial Arts Classes

Most parents who enroll their children into these classes can notice positive changes in their personalities right away. As children spend more and more time training and learning these techniques they become more and more centered and self-assured. Most of the techniques taught through this arts rely on the repetitive training on particular movement unless and until the student is perfect in a particular move. This form of training helps children to tap into the innate ability to focus and produce results which in turn makes them more and more content and confident. Renowned classes like taekwondo also build effective social skills as the teachings help children in maintaining and nurturing respectful relationships with their peers as well as their fellow students.

She said that she emphatically told the person, "NO YOU MOVE. MY SON IS TRYING TO GET ON THE MONKEY BAR." Was Sherri being a bully, or was she just being a Mommy?

Every kid who is being bullied has to figure out how to protect himself/herself. Once you know how to protect yourself from bullies, your self-esteem will dramatically increase. The martial art form of Jujitsu is no longer just for adults. Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu is fast becoming popular with parents and children alike with many martial arts schools specializing in offering Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu training.

Like adult instruction, Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu uses grappling techniques similar to judo. This technique enables development of stronger, more confident kids. The main attraction of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu to many has long been how smaller people can defend themselves from larger enemies through the use of these training techniques. Because kids are more likely to associate martial arts with Karate, they might not be familiar with what Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu training has to offer so it is wise for parents to introduce them to this popular style.

Check out these tips to help your child discover the benefits of training in Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu:

Tell your child about the history of Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu and how it is used to promote health and strength to young people. The founder of judo, Kano Jigoro, taught martial arts to kids with an objective to promote spiritual strength and physical fitness. The majority of the training centers offering Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu operate with the same values and philosophy.

Differentiate Judo, Karate and Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu. Inform your child that even though these martial arts have grappling and throwing techniques, Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu focuses on ground fighting techniques and the battle for dominance.

A child who is being bullied by other kids at school or community can benefit from Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu since it provides techniques that will enable a smaller person to overcome a larger enemy. Also, with the knowledge of Jiu-Jitsu, your child will be more confident and physically fit so bullying from other kids might never be an issue.

Have your child observe a Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu class in a local martial arts center so that they can be encouraged in enrolling themselves. Many schools offer sample classes for children to try out before committing to enrollment.

Remember that most all kids love physical contact and wrestling. Think of all the time you have spent playing on the floor with your child. Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu allows your child to enjoy this type of physical activity while learning an effective self-defense.

If your child already participates in Kids Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu classes, make sure that you show your support for their training and accomplishes as they continue in their lessons.

Most people know that karate and other martial arts classes require a lot of discipline. It's not easy learning the techniques, and your typical sensei is quite strict. But how does that translate into doing better at school?

You might be surprised, especially at how little time it takes to show a difference in your child's behavior in school. My daughter took her first martial arts classes in kindergarten (Tang Soo Do, to be specific), and her teacher commented in the first month that my daughter's behavior in class had improved. That's well before any belts were even possible to reach, aside from the introductory white belt that all students received at the end of the first class.

It's not just how kids behave in class that is improved, although that's a nice plus. There are more academic benefits to students who take karate and other martial arts classes.

Discipline

This goes beyond just behaving in class. There's always a goal to aim for in karate, whether it's reaching the next belt level or figuring out that new move. It's a lot of work, and that's good for kids to learn in one place, so they can apply it in school.

Some senseis take things a bit farther and will also discipline kids in karate class for misbehavior at school. Most have very high expectations for how their students behave in their lives as a whole, not just how they behave at the dojo or studio.

Focus

Martial arts training takes a lot of focus. Students really have to pay attention to understand exactly how each move is performed, even when the sensei shows it slowly.

That focus translates into how academic work is done. Kids learn to keep focus on their studies, which allows them to do it more quickly and accurately.

Build Memorization Skills

As your child advances in the martial arts, many forms have them memorize a kata, or a series of moves performed in a precise sequence. Even the early ones can be fairly complex, and take a lot of practice to memorize.

While academic work should not all be memorization, a significant part of it will relate to having memorized the basics. This is an important skill for any student to master.

Confidence

Learning a martial art is a great way to build a child's confidence. It's an amazing feeling to master a new skill, especially one that is so challenging. This is a great confidence builder.

It may not seem as though confidence is a skill much needed in school, but it truly can be important. Confidence means your child is more likely to speak his or her mind in discussions, or ask questions of the teacher. It can mean they cope better if they're bothered by a bully. It may help them to be less afraid to learn new things.

Hard Work Is Rewarded

Hard work in karate classes are rewarded when your child takes the test and earns either a new stripe on their belt or the next level belt. They won't get to the next level just for being in class; that stripe or belt must be earned. Karate helps them to see that they should respect their teachers, classmates, parents and others around them.

Unfortunately, the disadvantage to being raised in a small town is that if you are unlucky enough to be targeted by bullies, it can be more difficult to find places to hide.

Everything was great in grade school. My friends and I were all from the same side of our 10,000 person town and had spent years getting to know each other. I was an average sized kid for my age, but was a little more soft spoken and polite than a lot of the kids in my class. My teachers always loved me because I never got in trouble or disrespected them or other students. For me, the problems began in Junior High.

In my town, there were four grade schools and one junior high school. In seventh grade, all of the prior 6th graders were moved into the junior high school and mixed with kids from the other elementary schools. There was a small grade school that was on the outskirts of town that was part of this transition and included a little different breed of student than I had been used to. For the first couple of weeks of junior high, I clung to the friends I had known since kindergarten, but was also mixed into classes with many students I didn't know. Even though I was not a very coordinated child, I joined the football team so that I could at least feel like I was part of something. My problems really started when in algebra class.

I've always gotten good grades in math. Despite this, somehow I ended up in a math class with all of the juvenile delinquents in my school. I remember sitting in class feeling horrible about how disrespectful of the kids were being to the teacher. He tried all sorts of discipline techniques with no success and because I was the one student in the class who paid attention to him and treated him with respect, he used to give me favoritism to some of the other kids. This brought some negative attention in my direction. The kids in my class started by teasing and calling me names, but that quickly escalated into throwing things at me and pushing in the halls. My teacher did everything he could to protect me from the bullying, but it only got worse. I knew that if I went to the principal, it would only make things worse, and I didn't have the heart to tell my parents. At this point, I determined that if I wanted the bullying to stop, I would have to learn to fight.

Another unfortunate thing about living in my small town is that there was not a karate school that I could join. Up until now, I had only seen karate in the movies and had an unrealistic idea of what it entailed. Nowadays, I could probably just do some hunting online and find some great websites that would teach me martial arts through online videos, but the best I could do in my town was head on down to the library. Fortunately, the library did have a small section of martial arts books that I was able to check out. All of the books I brought home were very old and illustrated with black and white photography, but it was a start. I only wish I could have joined a dojo earlier in my childhood.
